events.title: Churchill delivers the Iron Curtain speech in Fulton
events.summary: Winston Churchill's 'Sinews of Peace' speech publicly framed postwar Europe as divided by an 'iron curtain' under Soviet influence.
events.impact: The speech accelerated policy alignment in Western capitals and became an early doctrinal marker of bloc confrontation.

events.title: Truman Doctrine formally commits U.S. to containment
events.summary: President Truman asked Congress to support Greece and Turkey and stated a broader policy of backing states resisting coercive takeover.
events.impact: U.S. foreign policy shifted toward sustained global containment, anchoring long-run Cold War security commitments.

events.title: Marshall Plan proposal launched for European recovery
events.summary: Secretary of State George Marshall proposed a large-scale U.S.-backed recovery program for war-damaged Europe.
events.impact: The program strengthened Western European reconstruction and institutionalized economic competition between blocs.

events.title: Soviet blockade of West Berlin begins
events.summary: Soviet authorities cut land and water access to West Berlin, triggering the first major Berlin crisis.
events.impact: The crisis hardened East-West separation, prompted the Allied airlift, and raised direct superpower confrontation risk.

events.title: North Atlantic Treaty signed, establishing NATO
events.summary: The United States, Canada, and Western European states signed the North Atlantic Treaty to institutionalize collective defense.
events.impact: A formal Western security architecture emerged, reshaping military planning and long-run risk pricing in Europe.

events.title: Soviet Union conducts first atomic bomb test
events.summary: The USSR carried out its first nuclear test at Semipalatinsk, ending the U.S. atomic monopoly.
events.impact: Strategic deterrence shifted to bilateral nuclear competition and intensified arms-race dynamics.

events.title: Korean War begins
events.summary: The outbreak of war on the Korean Peninsula internationalized Cold War confrontation in Asia.
events.impact: The conflict expanded alliance commitments, defense spending, and the proxy-war pattern of superpower rivalry.

events.title: Warsaw Pact signed
events.summary: The Soviet Union and allied Eastern European states established the Warsaw Pact collective defense framework.
events.impact: Europe's military bipolarity was formalized, increasing bloc-to-bloc force posturing and escalation pathways.

events.title: Berlin Wall construction starts
events.summary: East German authorities, backed by Soviet strategy, sealed the intra-Berlin border and began constructing the Berlin Wall.
events.impact: The Wall became the central physical symbol of Cold War division and entrenched systemic separation in Europe.

events.title: Cuban Missile Crisis becomes public and blockade begins
events.summary: President Kennedy publicly announced Soviet missile deployments in Cuba and imposed a naval quarantine.
events.impact: Nuclear confrontation risk spiked to extreme levels, driving later crisis-management and arms-control mechanisms.

events.title: Warsaw Pact invasion crushes Prague Spring reforms
events.summary: Soviet-led Warsaw Pact forces entered Czechoslovakia to halt reform efforts associated with the Prague Spring.
events.impact: The intervention reaffirmed Soviet coercive control in Eastern Europe and constrained reform pathways within the bloc.

events.title: SALT I and ABM Treaty signed in Moscow
events.summary: Washington and Moscow signed SALT I accords and the ABM Treaty, setting initial constraints on strategic systems.
events.impact: Strategic stability rules became partially institutionalized, reducing some first-strike incentives during detente.

events.title: Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan escalates into invasion
events.summary: Soviet forces entered Afghanistan and took direct control of the security and political center in Kabul.
events.impact: Detente deteriorated sharply, sanctions and geopolitical confrontation intensified, and long-run regional instability increased.

events.title: Reagan announces the Strategic Defense Initiative
events.summary: President Reagan announced a long-term research program to develop missile defenses later known as SDI.
events.impact: Strategic competition widened from offensive arms ceilings to high-technology defense races and bargaining leverage.

events.title: Gorbachev becomes CPSU General Secretary
events.summary: Mikhail Gorbachev assumed Soviet top leadership, beginning a reform era associated with glasnost and perestroika.
events.impact: Soviet policy flexibility increased, enabling later arms-control progress and reducing military intervention in Eastern Europe.

events.title: INF Treaty signed in Washington
events.summary: The United States and the Soviet Union signed the INF Treaty eliminating an entire class of land-based intermediate-range missiles.
events.impact: Verification-based disarmament improved confidence and materially reduced theater-level nuclear risk in Europe.

events.title: Berlin Wall opens and begins to fall
events.summary: East German authorities opened border crossings, and mass public action quickly dismantled the Berlin Wall's practical function.
events.impact: The event accelerated Eastern European regime transitions and signaled rapid collapse of the postwar bloc order.

events.title: Two Plus Four Treaty signed in Moscow
events.summary: The two German states and four WWII powers signed the final settlement treaty resolving Germany's external status questions.
events.impact: The agreement cleared core legal-security obstacles to full German sovereignty and reunification.

events.title: German reunification is formally completed
events.summary: The German Democratic Republic acceded to the Federal Republic of Germany, restoring a unified German state.
events.impact: European political-economic integration and post-Cold War security architecture were fundamentally reshaped.

events.title: Warsaw Pact is formally dissolved
events.summary: Warsaw Pact members formally terminated the alliance framework and its military-political structures.
events.impact: The institutional military pillar of the Eastern bloc ended, reducing bloc-to-bloc confrontation risk in Europe.

events.title: Soviet Union effectively dissolves after Gorbachev resignation
events.summary: Gorbachev resigned and Soviet state institutions ceased operating as a union-level superpower framework.
events.impact: The bipolar Cold War order ended and global strategic, fiscal, and commodity-risk regimes re-priced around a new system.
